segments.text: The Germans started coming in to surrender.
So we went on up to Paris.
We'd done all we could.
And stayed in the house of one of those requisitioned, beautiful gods there.
An ancient place that they requisitioned back then.
And on the night the war was declared to be over, oh hell, I might as well tell the story.
An old friend was commanding a fighter outfit.

came in with his Red Cross girl, and he didn't have any place to sleep, so I said, well, you can have my place, and if you take me across town to the Ritz, which is a commandeered hotel, I could get us a place there.
In fact, I called them there, and they sure could.
Well, we started across town, and Paris was just like that, and to make a long story short, it was a long time getting there, because
We had to, we got crowded and finally a big truck came by and we just crept behind it and went way around and got me out.
Next morning, another old friend showed up at breakfast and asked me, and I said, well, I'm going home as quick as I can.
I haven't got any way to go yet.
He said, hell, come on with me.
And he was stationed at Casablanca and I had to be 17 up there, one of those messed up ones.
And took me down there and
got me out on the first match flight back to the stage for Washington.
And as I went to go up the ramp, the sergeant stopped me and said I didn't have the right shots or something like that.
And I looked at him and said, sergeant, you don't think that's going to keep me off this airplane?
I looked like what I was, I guess.
And he said, no, sir.
And so I ended up in Washington.
And I guess it was around 2 o'clock in the morning.
And a young woman got me a hotel room, and I went to it and got a little sleep until in the morning.
See, I had to do this thing with the OSS, which was responsible for the other end of the pipeline.
Right, the OSS.
Yeah.
So they wanted to debrief you.
I had to.
There's no way about it.
And I had to write a report for the air staff.
Okay.
I wanted to get that done as quick as I could.
So when I finished the day, I went back to the hotel, got down to Muscovy's and started writing it out.
And the hotel clerk called me and says, why aren't you out of that room?
And I said, God damn, I registered in last night.
And he said, you can't keep it.
We've got to go.
You've got to go right now.
I said, I haven't got any place to go.
And he said, well, you've got to get out of here.
This was a hero's welcome.
I didn't know any of this.
I'd been gone so long I didn't know that Washington was jammed full of people.
So I said well let me try to find a room and I called and there was not a room.
And this I didn't want to do but I had to.
I called an old friend and asked him if I could stay with him.
So I did.
That was what you might call a year's welcome.
Now I don't mean to say that people didn't
weren't very good to me, they were.
But I didn't know, for example, about rationing.
I suppose it had it, but I never had to pay attention to it.
Well, this man and his wife, old friends, asked some women, friends of people that I'd seen in Europe, they hadn't got back yet, over to dinner.
Meantime, somebody had handed me a handful of ration coupons and God knows what.
tickets.
I didn't even know what they were.
So when I mentioned that, these ladies, and they grabbed them and took them.
They needed them.
They needed them bad.
I didn't know any of that.
So there was a good deal of getting used to for me.
But other than that, it was all right.
Now what did you write in your OSS report?
Well,
Some of it from back then was secret, not much.
The one thing that I hated to do, I had to do, was write a very derogatory report on a man who had not performed the duty that he had been ordered to perform.
And the upshot of that was that it ended up in a file
As you may know, there is a personnel file that's open at large, in board.
There's another file which isn't, and that's where it ended up.
And I didn't even know because I didn't care.
I'd done what I had to do.
I hated to do it because I'd known this man well.
He'd worked for me in the past.
But he didn't perform well in the POW camp?
It was something that I don't want to go in further with.
He's dead too, I might add, but

Years later, an old friend that I had in Washington who was a specialist in military court cases talked to me about it because he'd been hired to defend this man in a case he'd been kicked out of the service.
Oh, later he was kicked out of the service?
And that report was used and that was not what brought him before the
being kicked out.
It was another action.
But that report was brought out in the case, and the man was kicked out.
It was an appeal case, one of those final appeal cases, which my friend, the lawyer, was defending.
Well, was this report discussing the situation in prison, or in the POW camp?
Oh, I don't want to go into it.
It was just one of those things that you have to do that you hate to do.
No, not the camp, not with this man, not dealing with a man.
I'm talking about the other part of the report.
Well, the other part had to do really with the interests.
It was partly an interrogation by the people who are on this end of the pipeline.
And it was a tenuous, tortuous pipeline, but nevertheless it was there and I was on one end of it.
And you see,
I had to tell them what it was like from that end.
The things, the really important things that we tried to get back either didn't get back or were ignored.
Some of the other things did, and perhaps they did a little good, not much, I'm sure.
But a really useful intelligence from our point of view.
Not about us, but about what the Air Force could do.
It wasn't worthwhile.
Now, can you explain this pipeline?
I don't think I should.
It isn't as though it was quite secret then, and perhaps it is now, I don't know.
But I don't think it should.
I don't see any purpose to be served by it.
And if it were necessary to use a gun, something which I think is highly unlikely, you really wouldn't want to discuss too much.
Now when you came back from the service, or from the war, you were a colonel.
Were you thinking about getting out of the military?
A lot of people at this time, of course, there was a rapid demobilization.
Were you thinking about retiring from the military and becoming an engineer, or were you thinking about finishing out and having a full career?
Not at that time.
I did not too long after that.
I had an opportunity to make some money.
I made it, too, if I'd been out and done it.
What happened in that instance was that the Korean War came on and I just couldn't, in due conscience, I couldn't leave then.
And then the next time, well, be explicit about it, the guy that I furnished the paper to said, oh shit, tore it up and threw it in the wastebasket.
And I said, well, I'll do it later.
And it turns out that my duty
It was pleasant.
Well what duty did you have right after you came back?
You were assigned as Deputy Personnel 8 Air Training Command.
Was this in Washington?
No, no.
This was first at Fort Worth and then in Barksdale.
We moved the headquarters into Barksdale.
It's the headquarters which is now in San Antonio.
And you were a colonel at the time, and were you, many people, of course, had temporary rank at this time, and they were lowered in rank.
Did this happen to you?
Oh, no.
No, this did happen to a good many of my contemporaries.
Yeah.
All that I can remember were made again later.
Yeah.
No.
No, there's a peculiarity in it.
I was serving in what they call general slots, table organization slots.
From that time until the time I was promoted, which time I was serving in a colonel slot.
This is an anomaly in the service.
And it doesn't happen too often, but it happens.
It did to me anyway.
I'm just saying that those particular things don't mean a hell of a lot.
Okay, so were you at the Air Training Command then until how long?
When did you go to the Air War College?
Oh, it's when it first opened up.
I guess that would be in the summer of 46, wouldn't it be?
I guess that's when you're 47.
And what did you think of going back to school at the Air War College?
I enjoyed it.
Was it valuable?
Was it a valuable experience?
I don't like to answer the question that directly.
See, I spent two years in school when I was there.
What I learned out of it probably could have been learned in about a year.
Some of what I learned, for example, was applied in the National War College that I'd already had.
It's hard to evaluate military education because part of it is an association with people who have had different experiences than your own.
you learn from them rather than the curriculum.
And I think it can be done much quicker.
It's pretty goddamn expensive, too.
Oh, yes, it is expensive.
It definitely is.
And after your two years there, you were assigned to the Office for Atomic Energy.
This must have been about 1949 then?
Yeah, I guess so.
What did you think about the Air Force splitting from the Army?
That happened while I was in the school.
It is an inevitable.
See, people who were in my type of interest were particularly interested in that.
We had to depend on the Army in an ordinance for our armament.
People in the Army
couldn't know less about any subject than the requirements of air armament.
They didn't know and they didn't care and we were a goddamn nuisance to them.
We also were responsible, the quartermaster was responsible for furnishing certain items to us.
Our mission was so different to anything that they'd ever been familiar with that that was a serious handicap.
Having said that, and of course I can illustrate it with personal details, but I don't need to.
I want to point out that there are certain things that the Army does very well, and does better than the Air Force, which we probably should have left with the Army instead of taking along.
For example?
Burial service, post exchanges, commissaries, there are others.
certain of the engineering fields.
But we had to do it the way it was done.
And honestly, it was a must.
A lot of people thought it was, you know, gung-ho, wild beyond the deal.
It really wasn't.
It was the fact that we had to have more knowledgeable people
in the supporting functions than we could get in the Army.
And that is a simple thing to say, but it was goddamn difficult to work with.
And that's the why of it.
The whole boycott was like everything else like that.
It was a compromise.
The Navy didn't want it done.
The Army didn't want it done.
And in consequence, the triple service deal was a compromise.
Not a very good one, I might add.
But it works.

Now during the same time, not only did President Truman set up the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the three different branches, but he also started integrating the armed forces, which was carried out from 1947 through the Korean War.
What was your opinion of that?
Oh, this is balderdash, largely.
Let me talk about the best side of it first.
When I went from the Pentagon up to Sandia Base, that was an integrated command.
The commander was an Army officer.
I was the Air Force deputy and operations chief.
Navy deputy who was my deputy in operations.
Nevertheless, I was responsible for the Air Force guys, the Navy guy, and so forth.
This worked very well, but you don't know why.
Why?
There wasn't a man in it that wasn't specifically selected for it.
And during that time that I was there, and I won't go into them because some of them are still secret, but
When I put the finger on somebody to do something, and it might be in the Pacific, it might be in Europe, it might be in Kentucky, I didn't have to care whether he was Navy or Air Force or Army.
He was competent.
It's the only job I've ever had in my life.
I can say that.
So that's the good side of it.
But when you just throw them together, you don't get it.
That was unique because this was a new thing.
It was highly secret.
People thought it wasn't, but they thought it was hugely complicated and all that crap.
So when you got a Navy guy, he was the tops.
When you got an Air Force guy, he wasn't.
When you got an Army guy, he wasn't.
That's integration at its best.
And this was out, this is when you were with the Office of Atomic Energy.
No, that's when I was in the Special Weapons Corps.
Okay, Special Weapons out at Sandia, out in New Mexico.
Albuquerque.
Yeah, in Albuquerque.
Now, what were some of the special weapons that you were working on at that time?
Well, the bomb of course.
Yeah, and you were attempting to, as far as the bomb
were doing what with it?
Attempting to put it in guns?
Oh, hell no.
Oh well, I have to back off.
No.
Different types of warheads?
What you were doing, see you had to take care of them.
Had to have them ready for specifically the Air Force and mostly until a lesser degree but an appreciable degree the Navy.
And at
At the same time doing that, you had to do your goddamnedest to see that you had a better one coming on.
And equally important, that the service which was going to use it would be able to use it.
And the main problem in all that was that it was so goddamned secret.
Some of the people that should know things couldn't.
Some of the people who should know things wouldn't.
I'll illustrate that in one brief.

When LeMay came back from Europe to command SAG and move it to Omaha, I was in the Pentagon office and we made a specific impulsive effort to get him in that office to convince him that he had to have certain information which was under the peculiar
clearance system.
They had a clearance for this, clearance for that, clearance for that, clearance for that, and then there was a Q's clearance system, which was separate and all that.
Well, obviously, May had the highest clearance for Air Force data, top secret, but that was totally inadequate for this particular work under the law at that time.
So when we got to the nut cutting and wanted him to accept a stockpile clearance, he wouldn't do it.
There were only 13 people at the time that had one,
He wouldn't do it.
And he explained why he wouldn't do it.
He might have to lead a raid.
He might feel like he had to.
And if he had a stockpile clearance, he couldn't.
And so he wasn't going to do it.
I'm talking about a situation that's long since passed.
Yeah.
But it illustrates the problem of the time.
If he didn't know what the stockpile was, he didn't really know how many bombs he had to deal with.
That targeting system, which I worked on that too, if you didn't know that, you didn't really know whether your targeting system was worth a goddamn.
It's as simple as that.
But to eliminate those roadblocks which were built into the law,
The first Atomic Energy Act was a real son of a bitch of a job.
And it certainly was not finished by the time I left, not by a hell of a lot.
But it's infinitely better now, infinitely better.
We're getting into that philosophical area that I mentioned earlier where the technology is a given.
The technology that we were dealing with
in my opinion, was relatively simple.
Now, the scientific studies that led into it were not.
They were, for me, difficult, very difficult.
And when I say that, I want you to know that, well, Oppenheimer in the beginning and later Teller and Gamow were familiars in our office.
Sometimes I understood what they were talking about, sometimes I didn't.
But the technology of the weapons system, I understood that because it was simple.
But the problems were outside of that.
The problems were what you might call oversimplified political and administrative.
Now during this time, or a little bit later, Oppenheimer and Teller split over the issue of the hydrogen bomb.
And you were there at the time?
It was one of the country's great tragedies.
Oh, would you explain?
I hate to do it.
It was a tragedy.
It was a tragedy of the first order.
Let me
I don't want to do it, but I'll make one illustration.

When I was in this office in the Pentagon, a man in the Joint Chiefs who had been assigned to the job called me in because, after all, I'd known him for years, too, and he knew my background, and asked me specifically whether or not we should design the H-bomb.
I said, no, we shouldn't, but we've got to.
Now, that sounds like a contradiction, doesn't it?
It isn't.
That illustrates the tragedy of Oppenheimer Teller.
What kind of men were those two?
There's been a lot written about them by historians, and I just like, you knew them, and I like your personal view.
Both great men.
Unquestionably great men.
And it's just so very tragic that this had to happen.
And I don't want to go into the details of it, but I will say this, that a true blood-blooded, everlasting horse's ass was the cause of it.
It didn't have to happen, but it did.
That's not in any of the history books, and I'm not going to put it in any of them either.
Who are you referring to?
Senator McCarthy?
Oh, no.
No, no.
The man I'm talking about is Horst.
That's one of the military service.
That ain't to say that the military doesn't produce a lot of them.
Who is this man?
He's dead.
So is Oppenheimer.
I don't want to talk about it anymore.
You can get the book.
There's one recently published on Oppenheimer.
I don't think I ought to.
I'll tell you who can tell you if he will.
And his poise may be utterly different to mine.
That's Al.
I've talked to him about it.
He's a lot closer to it than I was.
I just...
I totally deplore it.
I don't know what Al thinks about it.
I've never discussed it with him.
In fact, I never discussed anything much with him.
I doubt that he even remembers me.
I doubt it.
No, I don't see any point in expressing myself on this.
If you didn't have that goddamn thing on, I wouldn't mind it.
But I just don't believe that I should.
Now, let's talk about when the Korean War erupted, 1950.
Where were you at that time?
Boy, that's one I won't forget.
I don't know whether you want this in the history or not, but it still amuses me.
I was out in San Diego.
the several factors involved in this particular undertaking.
But the fact of the matter was that the production in a certain area of the deal I was working on was more than really needed.
And there was a way, and it's
You've heard of it if you don't know about it.
It's a breeder system in which you could get in effect something for nothing and if you needed more you could save yourself a lot of trouble.
And it's self-evident if you had all the information, that's the key, that the production was more than we needed.
I drew up a study on that.
Didn't do it all by myself.
Had a better man on it than I am on that kind of thing.
And as was customary and needed back then, taped the goddamn thing to my stubble, put my clothes on, put the pistol, obligatory pistol.
You couldn't go without it if you had that kind of material with you.
And that was pretty, look, you can't get that pistol like that in there.
If you need it in the heart.
Got in my airplane and started to Washington.
Well, we had a station over in Kentucky.
It was an Air Force station, and I was anywhere responsible for it, although I did not command it.
The commander met me at the airplane.
I was just going to do a cursory look and fuel up and go on.
And he said the North Koreans had invaded.
I said, well, so what else is new?
I'd known they'd do that for a long time.
I thought everybody did.
I still don't understand.
Everybody that
was familiar with that place and knew it.
All the people that I'd known that had come back from there knew it.
Nevertheless, I said I went on into Washington.
The Pentagon was like that.
I ditched my study when I saw that it was probably without question that you could get anybody's attention at a place where they burned things like that and started on home.
back to Albuquerque because that particular operation totally fruitless still is, I expect, because of other things.
Now, I stopped in at Maxwell and had an old friend down there who was assigned to plans and he was absolutely ecstatic.
He said, this is the chance to prove air power.
We're going to save that peninsula with air power.
Somebody, my God, and God I don't know who it was, got to Truman with the same notion.
And Truman publicly said, we're going to do it with sea and air power.
That is absolute bullshit.
You couldn't do it that way.
You can't do it that way.
You'll never be able to do it that way.
Somehow, someway, Truman accepted it.
That's how the damn thing started, from my experience.
Later on I went out there, but that's another part of the question you asked.
Well, later on you went out there in what capacity?
Again, on a special mission type deal.
A special mission doing what?
We had, we were...
designing a different kind of weapon for a different purpose.

And the problem for the part of San Diego base that I was responsible for was to make sure that we had organized and trained the men who would have to take care of that particular weapon for that particular mission.
Okay, they were having a big war over there.
This is a pretty good place to go find out.
In addition, I had two other missions.
One was to target to see if the bombs we had would be of use in that situation.
That's as simple as I can put the problem.
The answer to that was no.
And the other one was a real divvy.
The Army wanted a shell.
You know, they later got one.
that would fire out of a great big cannon, they got that too.
And to find out from the people who were under the gun, in other words the army people out there, whether that was a good idea, and it wasn't, but we got it anyway.
That's what it was.
Why do you say that the atomic gun idea is not a good idea?
Oh look, the thing couldn't shoot, I'm not talking about a missile, I'm talking about a gun.
Yeah, I know.
goddamn thing at best could only shoot 15 miles and anybody that's ever been in a situation in combat, fluid situation, knows damn well you can't do it.
You can't do that.
Look, let me go one step further on that.
They got a couple of those things in Europe and
One day I was stationed over there and I had to go into Germany on some kind of a long term business.
I didn't fly because I didn't want to leave the airplane over there and I didn't, we were tied up so I drove.
I guess I wanted to carve out some personal use, something like that.
And here's this goddamn cannon to shoot the thing that was falling from here to the road, the street in front, over in the ditch.
Ten days later, when I came back, it was still there.
Why?
They couldn't get it out.
You can't use anything like that in a fluid situation.
And the men... Just couldn't move it.
No.
They wouldn't dare to put the thing where they could use it.
And the men, the combat...
men that I talked to about it just laughed and they didn't even want to talk to me about it.
They thought it was so ridiculous that anyone would have that idea.
I don't know how you got me off on that subject.
I just asked you about it.
Oh, that's not the only stupid billion dollar weapon we've got.
Now you said before when we were talking about the Pentagon that you took your report from Sandia base out to the Pentagon when the Korean War started.
And then you made the comment that I took it to the Pentagon and they burnt it like they burned a lot of other things.
Now do they burn your report?
Oh yeah, sure.
Is it typical behavior of the Pentagon to burn reports instead of file them?
Didn't you ever hear of a burn basket?
Let me illustrate that with one more personal deal.
I had an office far into the
dead end hall.
And the scoop was that the material that came over from the Atomic Energy Commission building across the river to my place of business, part of it would come on one bridge and part on the other.
And they'd come under the outer office and the guy would sign it in to me.
He couldn't see it.
and we'd get into my office and we'd put it together.
I had a young woman secretary and she was highly comfortable.
She was as cleared as I was.
She wasn't cleared for numbers, but she was cleared for all she needed to be cleared for.
All right.
My duty was to take this true stuff and build it into something that could be used in the Air Staff without
compromising the security of it.
And when we were through with it, we had to go through a procedure to burn it.
I had a big, big safe in the office you could walk in.
It was a great big damn thing and heavy and you couldn't get in it, except that girl and I.
All right, the security officer came to me one day,
and said that he'd been asked to account for a paper, which, in his records, was in my office.
It wasn't.
And I didn't sign for these things.
The system was different.
The poor bastard that was the security officer signed for them.
He didn't even know what I did with them.
I told the young lady we had to have it.
not to secure him, but to get back to the other side of the river, if necessary, or proof of burn it.
There's a way to do that, numbers.
She didn't know either.
And she said, oh, God damn.
And went to the place in this big safe where she cut up things for the burn basket.
And she started scratching through it.
and found a little piece of paper about that big.
This sounds stupid.
It's a true story.
This was Friday afternoon.
Okay, it's in there.

I wasn't very good at it, but all day Saturday and all day Sunday, she came in and sat on her duff on the floor, fortunately it was carpeted, and fiddled with those goddamn little bitty pieces of paper until she put them all together, and there is the paper.
So we cleared it.
Well, is it common practice for the military to be burning official U.S. government documents?
Oh, you have to sometimes.
Well, as a historian, that's somewhat disturbing to me.
It shouldn't be.
They don't burn enough of them.
Especially now that this law has changed.
Look.
This particular study that I mentioned, which got us off on this, was a dead issue.
Because this thing that happened in Korea started a whole new thing.
I don't want to overdo this.
What I guess I was trying to illustrate is that the secrecy was a handicap.
Let me illustrate one more time, twice as a matter of fact.
Broder, who wrote The Ultimate Weapon, wasn't cleared for all those things, but nevertheless he's pretty good.
Who's this now?
David Broder, Brody, Broder.
Broder?
Yeah.
David Broder?
Journalist?
The journalist, David Broder?
Yes, yes.
Okay, David is Broder.
At that time, he was working, and when I first knew him, he was working at the War College.
Yeah.
And there's a story about that, but it doesn't fit, so I'll tell it.
We discussed this without going into the numbers.
He's strongly suspected, but he's one pretty smart man and well-informed.
That might be true.
people like him.
What might be true?
That we were overproducing.
Overproducing what?
Overproducing the component of the weapon for its needs.
And that there probably was a better way to go about it.
But when you get war historia all over
The signals of the ball game changed right then.
I'll tell you one more thing about this.
Well, what happened to Broder?
You were going to tell me about him.
Well, frankly, I don't know.
I'd like to know.
I haven't seen him or heard of him in God knows how long.
No, you were telling me that he got the feeling that we were overproducing too many atomic bombs, and then what happened?
The only reason I mention him is that this man is a pretty talented writer.
Yeah.

And when he came out to Sandia with this on his mind, and he had a clearance for a certain amount of information, I didn't talk to him about what I was going to do or had to do, but he was very helpful because he can write and I can't.
I can write simple declarative sentences, but I'm not very good at a long dissertation type thing, and he is.
I owed him something out of it.
So how did he help you?
I don't know whether he knew that I was doing it.
I don't think he did.
I don't know.
I don't think so.
I don't think he could have.
My boss did out there, and he agreed with it.
You mean letting him see documents?
Oh, no, I didn't.
No, not about that.
I couldn't.
Or telling him about...
I'm talking about secrecy.
Uh-huh.
No, I couldn't do that.
Look, I said...
But he wanted some information.
There were only 13 people in the whole goddamn United States that had the key information.
And I mean by key information was without that,
Jesus, there are a lot of these things that you couldn't explain.
This is no longer true.
This is long since past.
Everybody that I know of that needs to know these things now knows them.
Now what was considered the key information at that time?
How many bombs we had?
That type of information?
Or what was it?
That type of information.
Jesus Christ
There were some other features of it that had to do with simple technology that it would be hard to believe could get so screwed up.
We built them.
I don't want to talk about it.
You built a what?
The Air Force built some equipment that
Didn't even fit what it had to do because of this.
This is a story that's closed book.
It's long since past.
It's no longer true.
But let me illustrate it with one more story.
George Gamow, teller incidentally, if you don't know, is a Hungarian.
Gamow is a Russian.
born and educated in Russia.
He got out of Russia, and that's a story in itself.
Gamow was not cleared for anything.
I was in this job in the Pentagon, and we were trying to establish an archives, as it were, a place where the information was that we could put in it, that people needed to know.
That was at Wright-Patterson.
This key subject, hell no, you couldn't put that in there.
You couldn't put it anywhere.
But nevertheless, that which had to do with the technology of the weapon system, yes, we could, and we were doing it.
Okay, one morning I showed up for work in the Pentagon, and here in my mail was a dispatch from Wright Patterson.
Say, isn't this top secret?
And I opened it, and it was a little brochure written by Gamow.
You're goddamn right it was top secret.
He'd written it straight out of his head.
He wasn't cleared for anything.
But it was just as top secret as anything could be.
But as far as he was concerned at the time, it was a theory about how you built the bomb.
That illustrates the difference.
You see, the scientists knew goddamn well that this
wasn't top secret, but other people didn't, specifically the Congress when they passed the first law.
When Eisenhower came into office, not immediately, but within time, he got the law changed and it was infinitely better.
But I'm talking about the original Atomic Energy Act and the
and the secrecy that was written into that act.
One of the things that I think military people should be sensitive to, at least I always felt it should be, is law.
Don't give a damn whether you agree with it or not, you've got to obey it.
If you find a regulation, then God knows you'll proliferate.
You can bend or break one of them, but if it's solidly built on a log, you don't.
You've got to change the law.
That's the nature of government in the United States.
That's what the military has to do in order to preserve itself.
It's got to stay out of these things that the politicians do.
Now tell me about this one trip that you made to Korea.
Why did you go there?
Why did they send you?
I wanted to go, of course.
What was the objective of the mission?
What I stated, first we had our training mission.
Next, what I was specifically assigned out of Washington, it had to do with the bomb and the usefulness of it in that situation.
And finally that thing that they hung on to just before I was about to leave was whether or not the Army weapon was justified.
What did you think about Douglas MacArthur's idea of using the bomb north of the Yalo River?
